Message.Title: Are things too good for the traders?
Message.Msg: 208,000 jobs added per month for the past 6 months. April jobs higher than expected. May report out in a week. Consumer confidence at an all time high. Unemployment lowest in 5 years. Number of hours worked increasing every month. Housing market picking up. Companies setting on mountains of cash. And the fear is... the fed will stop providing low cost money for bankers and investors because the economy is in recovery. We have side by side economic experiments here and in Europe. Austerity in Europe has led to prolonged recession while stimulus here has led to steady recovery. Traders care less about whether a company is doing a good job. The only criteria is what is the short term return. An investor places money with a company to see it grow and prosper. Because stock prices always fall faster than they rise shorting makes fast attractive money for those who care nothing about the consequences to the company. When trades cost $100 and the uptick was 12.5 cents and there were not computers trading faster than humanly possible there was more incentive to be an investor.

Topic.Title: country wide credit

Message.Msg: Read the 10Q report as spock suggests. CWC is pretty much buried and dismembered within BAC now. But it appears the drag on BAC by CWC is abating. In January they settled with FNMA with cash and put backs and in April they settled in three class action suits related to CWC. Meanwhile, mortgage banking income for Q1 was $1.26 billion. That was downYOY because of a smaller mortgage portfolio and lower production, but still profitabie. All in all, the mortgage biz is improving along with the recovery in the housing market.

Topic.Title: Is this the week that Holder finally gets indicted?

Message.Msg: An FBI affidavit used to obtain the warrant for Rosen's e-mails said there was probable cause the reporter had broken the law when he allegedly received a leaked classified report from a State Department contractor named Stephen Kim. The affidavit described Rosen as potentially being an "aider and abettor and/or co-conspirator" to the crime of disclosing government secrets, opening up criticism that the Obama administration was targeting Rosen. However, the Justice Department did not prosecute Rosen, nor did it file charges against him. While he was listed as a "co-conspirator," that often times does not mean he would be considered a target. The Justice Department official on Thursday said that prosecutors have never sought to bring criminal charges against Rosen, meaning Holder's testimony was accurate. "The search warrant application in the Kim matter was focused on obtaining evidence relating to allegations that a government official had leaked highly classified information, which was a threat to our national security," the Justice official wrote. "The warrant application was drafted during the investigation phase of the case, which came before any decisions about prosecution. And nearly three years after completing our thorough investigation of the Kim matter, the Department does not anticipate bringing any additional charges. During the Attorney General's tenure, no reporter has ever been prosecuted."

Topic.Title: Back to the markets. You people better be watching the 10 year bond. If interest rates skyrocket this market will collapse.

Message.Msg: Low interest rates bring investment in to areas of production. Junk bonds and derivatives just create a false paper economy that allows the easy transfer of paper at higher and higher prices. The real worth of an economy are the goods and services it produces. That comes from labor. When no labor is involved the values are only abstract and as fleeting as tulip bulbs. The better you provide jobs so all can be productive the better off we all become. To do that you need investors, not hedge funds and traders.

Message.Title: 8.5 Billion Settlement Hearing
Message.Msg: Tomorrow will mark the beginning of what will decide the future for Bank of America. If the settlement is ultimately approved, it is very possible that BAC will reach 17 in the short term. the settlement is rejected, BAC will trade back down to the 11s. My view is that BAC will prevail and LONGS will be rewarded for their patience. I have held this stock and followed it since 2008 and this breakout is for real. i was skeptical of Moynihan at first and he made some PR mistakes, but he has done a masterful job of paying down debt, reducing risk, managing litigation, and delivering on his word. Good luck to all BAC investors out there over the next several days and weeks - there will be leaks and reports from the courtroom that will add gut wrenching volitility - hang in there and you will be rewarded.

Topic.Title: Will there be a court decision tomorrow?

Message.Msg: If you mean judicial decision on Article 77 I believe that has been postponed due to the petition raised by the Intervenors to the Appellate Court after the ruling by Judge Kapnick. Judge Kapnick has ruled that there will be no jury trial and this was a judicial disappointment to AIG and others (objectors) so they are no appealing, Judge Kapnick: "And therefore, I grant the petitioner's or institutional investors' motion to strike the jury demand. So we are not going to have a jury. I don't know if there is anything else to discuss today"
